history.text: hello
hello, have you seen The Shape of Water?
yes I saw it literally just now. how about you?
I saw it about a week ago. Did you enjoy it?
no I didn't enjoy it. it seemed like just a showcase of cinematic effects and CGI and I didn't really think the storyline was thoughtful.
I also don't know any of the actors Sally Hawkins, Michael Shannon, Richard Jenkins, Octavia Spencer, or Michael Stuhlbarg
I'm only familiar with Octavia Spencer. She played Zelda in the film. She's a talented actress.

Are you familiar with the director, Guillermo 
de Toro?
No I've never heard of anything else del Toro has directed. I take it you enjoyed the film?
I did enjoy the film but I thought it was a little too predictable. So similar to you, I thought it could have been more thoughtful.
It received good scores though...92% from Rotten Tomatoes and 87/100 from Metacritic
Yes, the film has many fans. You wouldn't think it from reading the basic description of a mute custodian who falls in love with an amphibian creature.
Did you know the premise before you watched it?
I generally don't like coincidental plot or character devices like...why is a mute woman working in such a top secret government facility?
no I didn't know anything about this film. What do you think about the possibility of it being either based on real life or released to discredit us from thinking this could happen in real life?
And at the height of the Cold War too!
All I have to say is that it left me with more questions than answers...if you know what I mean.
Also, they have a Soviet spy working there at the top secret facility.
I think I know what you mean...it has some very strange scenes doesn't it?
Yes, it most certainly does.
Wow it has some very strange scenes indeed...are they trying to promote interspecies relationships or is it an allegory for interracial relationships you think?
I hoped they would also share more about her neighbor, Giles.
All I know is that he was bald and had good taste in naming cats.
I don't even know. The interspecies element through me for a loop. I think it kind of wanted to shock the audience.
Ha ha!
The Giles character had a strong relationship with Elisa (the mute cleaner) but I didn't know why.
It's definitely shocking but I feel like Hollywood is responsible for putting these kinds of things on the "big screen", which I also think they're not doing so well these days in general.
Elisa keeps the creature in her bathtub but I kept wondering about the amount of salt needed to make a saline environment. Seemed like she would need to strictly measure the salt.
It appears to have had another one of those coincidental, Deus ex Machina endings. The "happily ever after" ending where things happen to line up just right.

I agree that Hollywood isn't
 doing too well these days.
I would say it's due to a lack of creativity but this movie seems to be overcompensating for that a little bit!
The making of the saline environment is another one of those coincidental things that happens I was talking about :)

Yes, maybe that's what people are demanding too. Give them a realistic ending and they automatically believe the movie was bad. Doesn't make sense. The character Giles was startled when he found the creature eating his cat, Pandora. I expected him to be more than "startled".
Yeah I feel like realistic endings AND story lines are what Hollywood needs more in it's movies
Yes, and giving an ultimatum of 36 hours seems like a strange number of hours. Anyway, nice chatting with you. Best of luck in whatever you do.
Yep it was nice chatting. Good to agree on the Hollywood thing and likewise
